Young Thyrsis, the thoughtless and gay,</br>Was first at each Revel and Sport;</br>He frolick'd most jocund the Day,</br>At Eve to each Nymph paid his Court.
Wherever a Pastime, or Show,</br>Caus'd Pleasure's gay Circle to meet,</br>Young Thyrsis was certain to go—</br>His Presence gave Zest to the Treat.
The Sports of the Chase and the Field</br>Afforded to Thyrsis delight;</br>The Joys that sweet Musick can yield,</br>Crown'd often with Rapture his Night.
The Old and the Prudish repin'd</br>The Heir of their Lord was so wild;</br>But those who well knew him could find</br>He candid was, courteous, and mild.
At Length good Acasto, his Sire,</br>Met Time — who had Charge of his Doom;</br>The Shepherds all wept, and each Lyre</br>Tun'd mournfully over his Tomb.
Now Thyrsis is Lord of the Dale,</br>And throws all his Foibles aside;</br>His Actions his Goodness reveal;</br>The Villager's Patron and Pride!
Acasto's good Deeds, and mild Worth,</br>As Brilliant in Thyrsis appear;</br>So Britain!  in Time will burst forth</br>The Virtues of George in his Heir.</br>
